<s>14<\s>24 
similar conditions with this difference only that the climatal 
change has only advanced so far in Kotzebue Sound as to 
gradually melt the ice cliffs and thus cause the coast line 
mapped by Admiral Kotzebue (1) to become lower and in 
every respect very much changed in the last eighty years, while 
in Somersetshire the arctic conditions have entirely passed 
away. The low-level gravels of the Lo<s>x<\s>cksbrook also near Bath which possibly 
may be of the same date as those of Freshford have afforded 
remains of <s>c<\s>Cave lion Tusk-elk Mammoth and Tichorine Rhinoceros. 
The absence of the Musk Sheep from the bone caverns of this 
district from which such vast stores of remains have been 
obtained from Banwell, Bleadon, Durdham  down, Uphill 
Hutton, Sandford Hill, Burrington and especially Wookey Hole 
Hyena-den, <s> in which one or other of the animals occur<\s> does not 
prove that they have no relation to the river bed of Freshford 
The Bison, Mammoth, Reindeer or Horse associated with the 
Musk sheep have been found in nearly all those caverns, and 
therefore I think it very probable they were open, while the 
latter animal was ranging on the banks of the Avon and that 
its rarity was the cause of its not having been yet discovered. 
In Germany the animal has been found in three localities 
In 1846 the discovery of a skull in the neighbourhood of 
Merseburg was put on record by M. Giebel (2), and Sir Charles Lyell 
also quotes in his Antiquity of Man, a skull in the Museum of 
Berlin, correctly named by Professor <s>q<\s>Quersted (3) as far back as 1836 
which has been dug up out of drift in the Kreuzberg in the 
southern suburbs of that city. The Mammalia associated with it 
were[?] Horse, Ox, Mammoth and Tichorine Rhinoceros (4), the third instance 
of its occurrence, is afforded by Professor E.E. Schmid (5) of the university 
of Jena who describes in the Neues Jahrbuch of 1863 a portion of a 
skull found in 1862 in the ancient alluvium of the Saale.
